section.title: Introduction
section.para: Biomedical terminologies are increasingly important resources for knowledge management, data integration, and decision support across healthcare contexts. The growing use of digital health data is accelerating the adoption of standard terminologies such as SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, and RxNorm. The interoperability of digital health data requires that healthcare organizations integrate subsets and modules of various reference terminologies and manage dependencies, versions, and new releases. As a result, there is a need for standardized representation of concepts that includes change management capabilities.

This section focuses on how the Terminology Knowledge Architecture (Tinkar) addresses the need for standardized semantics with versioning. The modeling guide establishes the processes and outputs for modeling domain Concepts in the Tinkar specification. The guide explains the data interoperability requirements Tinkar is intended to address, provides an overview of the Tinkar Modeling Process, and describes how the model can be applied to a unique data set. The Tinkar Modeling Guide does not encompass all the information regarding the Tinkar Reference Model. Therefore, it is encouraged to review the HL7 informative ballot to supplement this guide.

section.title: What is Tinkar?
section.para: Tinkar is a logical model designed to establish a robust knowledge architecture. Its primary goal is to integrate local systems with medical and laboratory terminologies like SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, etc., facilitating effective communication of clinical information across multiple systems. Tinkar is intended to support health care organizations’ standard terminology modules, value sets, and coding systems, as well as local terms and equivalence mappings. This allows organizations to tailor their terminology standards to specific needs. Enterprises can extend their terminology standards and rapidly implement extensions, enabling swift adaptation to evolving healthcare requirements.

section.title: Why Tinkar
section.para: Information systems across healthcare record and manage clinical data using clinical statements and clinical terminologies in non-standardized ways. Interoperability specifications aim to require terminology bindings to Concepts, code systems, and reusable value sets. There is currently variation in clinical data exchange across the enterprise as existing payloads and clinical statements use inconsistent and highly variable enterprise terminologies. Managing the Concepts, code systems, and value sets is complex because developers, implementers, and end users are forced to handle unnecessary complexity. For example:

listitem.para: In the representation of medication, RxNorm codes overlap with CVX codes. Investigational vaccines from the FDA are not represented in RxNorm, CVX, or SNOMED CT®.
In the representation of COVID-19, result codes are inconsistent and are not equivalent (e.g., detected, undetected, positive, negative, etc.).

section.title: Tinkar Logical Model
section.para: Before representing a data set using the Tinkar Logical Model, it is essential to understand the Tinkar starter data of Concepts, Patterns, and Semantics. The goal is to use what already exists in Tinkar and only create new Components when needed. This section provides a basic overview of the Tinkar Logical Model. The full description of the logical model is in the HL7 ballot, linked in the Introduction of this document.

The Tinkar Logical Model consists of three main Components: a Concept, a Pattern, and a Semantic. These Components ensure that data is consistently processed across different systems by defining the context and relationships of the data elements. This helps maintain uniformity in data interpretation, which is crucial for effective interoperability. The model can represent any knowledge standard, while still allowing for traceability and transparency of the data.

section.title: Components
section.para: The main objects in Tinkar are called Components. There are three distinct types: Concepts, Patterns, and Semantics. Every Component in Tinkar is represented by an array of at least one Universally Unique Identifier (UUID). A Component can be represented by multiple UUIDs if derived from multiple sources. For example, the Concept Acetaminophen, which exists in SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, and RxNorm, could have a UUID from each terminology and be represented as an array of UUIDs for this single Concept within a Tinkar implementation.
Every Component consists of a set of change records called Component Versions. Each version has an associated STAMP (Status, Time, Author, Module, Path).

section.title: Concepts
section.para: A Concept in Tinkar is a Component identified using Universally Unique Identifiers (UUIDs) and a STAMP. It contains only the information within the STAMP. Concepts have no emergent meaning. For example, Acetaminophen can be represented by attaching the description ‘Acetaminophen’ to a Concept with a UUID and no other additional information. Additional information is provided by Semantics. The specific meaning, purpose, and data elements of a Semantic are defined by a Pattern.

section.title: Patterns
section.para: A Pattern is created to make a new table and describes the fields and field types for the table, similar to a database. A Pattern is a Component that contains a Semantic Meaning, Semantic Purpose, and possibly a set of field definitions. A field definition has its own purpose, meaning, and datatype. These field types describe what type of information and what format the data in a Semantic following in this Pattern will be. The field definitions are equivalent to defining the columns in a database table. Using the Pattern, Semantics with varying fields and field types can be specified to represent any structure needed to provide meaning to a Component. There are three key Patterns used to represent terminologies via Tinkar: the Description Pattern, the Identifier Pattern, and the Stated Definition Pattern. The table below illustrates the Description Pattern as an example. The Description Pattern is one of the three key Tinkar Patterns. It has four different fields, each with associated field definitions.

The meaning and purpose Concepts shown in the above table for the Description Pattern are also types of Concepts in Tinkar, each with its own definitions. The table below shows the definition for the meaning and purpose Concepts from the Description Pattern table. Note how sometimes the meaning and the purpose is the same.

table.title: Description Pattern Meaning and Purpose Concepts

row.entry: Purpose and meaning for the description Pattern and dialect Patterns
Purpose and meaning for the description Pattern and dialect Patterns
The Semantic value indicating which language is used in the description text
Specifies the language of the description text.
Captures the human readable text for a description in Komet
Human readable text for a Concept
Specifies how to handle the description text in terms of case sensitivity
Specifies how to handle the description text in terms of case sensitivity
Specifying what type of description, e.g., fully qualified, or regular, etc.
Specifying what type of description, e.g., fully qualified, or regular, etc.

section.title: Semantics
section.para: To give machine-readable meaning to Components, Tinkar uses Semantics. A Semantic is a Component that contains a set of fields about the subject (the meaning and purpose defined by its Pattern). A Semantic provides meaning to the Components it references through its fields. A Semantic supports the specification of value sets, compositional definitions, and other Components requiring internal structure, and it specifies the nature of the compositional relationship explicitly.

A Semantic contains the data values, the referenced Pattern, and potentially multiple fields depending on the referenced Pattern. The referenced Component is the Component that is getting assigned the values in the fields. If table 1 represents the Pattern, the records inside that table are the Semantics. The referenced Pattern defines exactly how many fields a Semantic must have and their data type. The values in a field must match the corresponding field type defined in the field definition from the Pattern. If a Pattern has no field definitions, then a Semantic of that Pattern will have no fields. These are referred to as Membership Patterns and Semantics.

For example, the Concept of Acute Pelvic Pain requires additional information to accurately describe it. This information is all asserted by one or more Semantics of one or more Patterns (possibly multiple descriptions, a logical definition, etc.). Examples of such assertions include descriptions of the Concept, its fully qualified name, and unique relationships associated with the Concept.

section.title: STAMP
section.para: The STAMP in the Tinkar Reference Model allows for capturing a complete change record of all changes to a Component. It includes the Status, Time, Author, Module, and Path. As a model changes and evolves, changes are made in Components. With each change, a new change record and a new STAMP Coordinate are created. To track information like when and who made the changes, a STAMP is assigned to each version to record and preserve the history.
The following describes each of these attributes:

Status – A status is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information. For example, inactive or active. The tables below show the parent and children Concepts aligned to Status.

row.entry: The status represented by the STAMP (Active, Cancelled, Inactive, Premundane, Withdrawn)
Concept used to represent the original default status when creating a Concept that has not transitioned to a different status.

In the Premundane status, Components can move to the Active or Cancelled statuses. Since primordial Components were never committed to a database, they cannot be move to the Inactive or Withdrawn statuses.
When a new Component has been created but nothing is assigned nor has it been approved, it would have a Premundane status.

Concept used to represent a status for Components that are canceled. This means it was never successfully committed to the database. This state would be local only, and transient. It will eventually be removed from memory and will not propagate from one database to another.
The Cancelled status is a terminal status, meaning it cannot be moved from the Cancelled status back to a different status.

listitem.para: Created initially in the Premundane status but is deemed unnecessary

entry.para: It would be moved to Cancelled status.

row.entry: Concept used to represent a status for Components that are active.
In the Active status, Components can move to the Inactive status if a Component is no longer active, or it can move to the Withdraw status if the Component is realized to be a mistake.
A Component that was in Premundane status that has been fully reviewed and vetted will move to the Active status.
Concept used to represent a status for Components that are no longer active. This can be due to many reasons including the model changing or the Component was made obsolete by a new one.

In the Inactive status, Components can move to the Withdrawn status, if the Component is realized to be a mistake. In special circumstances with a good business reason, Components may be moved from Inactive back to Active.
If a Component committed to the Active status is no longer needed, it would be moved to the Inactive Status.

Concept used to represent a status for Components that are withdrawn. This indicates that a Component was successfully released, but that the Component’s release was a mistake, and all references to a withdrawn Component should be reassigned.
The Withdrawn status is a terminal status.
If a Component was accidentally created and committed to the Active status, it would be moved to the Withdrawn status.

section.para: When representing a new data set using the Tinkar Reference Model, only the status values above are allowed and must follow the business rules defined. The business rules do not account for the accidental moving of a Component. The diagram below shows the mapping between each status.

If the data set has additional status values beyond these five, such as the LOINC® Discouraged Status, they should be represented using an additional Pattern and Semantic. The STAMP status values must not be extended beyond the provided starter set. For example, using the LOINC® Discouraged Status, the status would be Active since it is in use. However, a Semantic would also be assigned to indicate it was Discouraged, capturing that additional information.
Time – The timestamp is captured with precision and a time zone. The table below shows the parent Concept aligned to Time.

entry.para: The timestamp is capture with precision and a time zone

section.para: Author – The author represents the author responsible for authoring the change. An author is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information. The tables below show the parent Concept aligned to Author.

row.entry: The author represents the author responsible for authoring the change. An author is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information.

section.para: Module – The module assigns the appropriate terminology (e.g., LOINC®) or terminology Component (SNOMED CT®). A module is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information. The tables below show the parent and children Concepts aligned to Module.

row.entry: The module assigns the appropriate terminology (e.g., LOINC®) or terminology Component (SNOMED CT®). A module is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information, such as organizing content for maintenance and publication purposes.

The default module assigned prior to creating other module Concepts. The primordial module is reserved for the starter set information that all Tinkar Reference Models require. Information that is specific to a particular data set (i.e., SNOMED CT®) should be contained in a module specific to that data set (i.e., a SNOMED CT® module)

section.para: Path – The path specifies version control within a development lifecycle, such as development, testing, staging, or production. A path is identified by a Concept and may be annotated with additional information. The tables below show the parent and children Concepts aligned to Path.

row.entry: A set of assets under version control that can be managed distinctly from other assets. Paths branch from other paths when established and can also be merged with other paths.

table.title: Path Children Concepts in the starter set. Additional paths may be created as need to organize development activities appropriately for a particular purpose (sandbox paths, feature paths, …)

row.entry: A path that contains Components that are shared across all paths and includes infrastructure Components.
A default path branch for Components. This path represents the published Components in production.
A path branch for Components under release. Once in this path, only minor changes such as bug fixes, documentation generation, and other release-oriented tasks can be added.
A path branch that specifies that the Components are currently under development.
A path branch for Components under testing.

section.para: Figure 3 illustrates the relationship between the five main paths detailed in Table 10 through which the project flows. The project begins in the Prerequisite Path, incorporating essential infrastructure Components shared across all paths. The established Components of the Prerequisite Path then move into the Master Path to create the first version of the project, known as Master 1. Rather than using a single path to showcase project flow, the Master and Development Paths record the project's history. The Master Path stores the official release history, while the Development Path serves as an integration branch for developing changes or features. Features are tested in the Sandbox Path, and approved Components are integrated into new project developments. Once a development has acquired sufficient Components for a new release, the project merges into the Release Path, signifying a release cycle where only minor changes, such as bug fixes, documentation generation, and other release-oriented tasks, can be added. When ready for official release, the project merges with the Master Path, creating a new version known as Master 2. This released Master 2 merges back into the Development Path, allowing the project to progress into the next phase of development.

section.title: STAMP Progression Examples in Component Versions
section.para: To understand how STAMPs are assigned to Component versions, the examples below illustrate STAMP functions and the design process behind them.

emphasis.emphasis: Example 1: Proposing a new SNOMED CT® Regular Name (Synonym) locally

section.para: In this example, a new Regular Name description for a SNOMED CT® Concept as a local extension is proposed. Since a new Semantic is being created, the new Component version requires a STAMP. In this example, the following parts are assigned:

row.entry: Status is set to Active since the Semantic should be active and visible.
The date and time when the Semantic was created.
The specific user account as a Tinkar Concept should be assigned.
Local Extension Module to SNOMED CT®
This is a local extension, not any official SNOMED CT® release.
This is a proposal for the new Semantic and not an officially reviewed Semantic.

emphasis.emphasis: Example 2: Testing different Pattern designs for approval and moving forward with one

section.para: In this example, three different Patterns to simulate storing experimental data in various ways are tested. These can be sent to another user who decides which Pattern they prefer and proposes to keep it while discarding the others.
Initially, all three Patterns have similar STAMP assignments:

row.entry: Status is set to Active since the Semantic should be active and visible.
The date and time when the Semantic was created.
The specific user account as a Tinkar Concept should be assigned. For this example, ‘Author 1’ is used.

entry.para: The Unique Module to specify the domain or data set that is being used.
The proposed Patterns are made for testing the data. They are not official or in development yet.

section.para: A second person may review these testing Patterns and, upon selecting a preferred design, update the Patterns to new versions, reflecting their decision in the STAMP for those Pattern versions.
The Pattern selected for retention:

row.entry: Status is set to Active since the Semantic should be active and visible.
The date and time when the Semantic was created.
The second person who chose the Pattern or ‘Author 2’.

entry.para: The Unique Module to specify the domain or data set that is being used.

row.entry: The proposed Pattern has moved into development and is waiting for official approval before it can be moved to the ‘Master Path.’

section.para: The Pattern selected for removal:

row.entry: The status is changed to inactive since the users will no longer use these Patterns.
The date and time when the Semantic was created.
The second person who chose the Pattern or ‘Author 2’.
The Unique Module to specify the domain or data set that is being used.
The proposed Patterns are still testing Patterns and not official or in development.

section.title: Tinkar Representation Examples
section.para: This section highlights examples of how common medical tests can be represented in Tinkar. The examples demonstrate how tests currently represented in both SNOMED CT® and LOINC® terminologies can be modeled in the Tinkar Logical Model.

section.title: Ex. 1 Urine Homocysteine
section.para: Figure 4 illustrates a Urine Homocysteine Test represented in the Tinkar Logical Model. The Concept contains both the description for the test as well as its corresponding UUID. This Concept serves as the subject for further classification. The Pattern uses field definitions to explain and categorize the corresponding Semantic fields. For example, LOINC® records the interval of time over which an observation is made. The time to conduct a Urine Homocysteine Test is 24 hours. Therefore, under the Time Field Definition within the LOINC® Pattern, the corresponding Semantic field would be 24H. While there are separate Patterns and Semantics for both SNOMED CT® and LOINC® terminologies, they are both connected to the original Concept.

section.title: Ex. 2 Substance concentration of glucose in specimen at point in time
section.para: Figure 5 illustrates a Substance Concentration of Glucose in Specimen Test represented in the Tinkar Logical Model. The Concept contains both the description for the test as well as its corresponding UUID. This Concept serves as the subject for further classification. The Pattern uses field definitions to explain and categorize the corresponding Semantic fields. For example, this test involves measuring the concentration of glucose in a given specimen. Therefore, under the Method field definition within the SNOMED CT® Pattern, the corresponding Semantic field would be Measurement – action. While there are separate Patterns and Semantics for both SNOMED CT® and LOINC® terminologies, they are both connected to the original Concept.

figure.title: Substance Concentration of Glucose in Specimen in Tinkar

section.title: Creating a Representative Tinkar Reference Model for a Data set
section.para: Creating a representative Tinkar Reference Model for a domain data set involves several key steps. The sections below detail the current Tinkar starter data and outline the steps for translating a data set into the Tinkar Logical Model.

figure.title: Key Steps to Represent a Data Set in Tinkar

section.title: Modeling Principles
section.para: There are specific principles to try and follow while executing the modeling process. These principles are detailed below.

listitem.para: For example, if a device identifier is sourced from a database like the Global Unique Device Identification Database (GUDID), you would not create a new Pattern to handle it. You should continue to use the Identifier Pattern already created in GUDID, but instead create a new Pattern to add any additional information needed (i.e., Is it a Primary DI or a Secondary DI? etc.) This new Pattern could then have Semantics referencing the identifier Semantic Components to give meaning.

emphasis.emphasis: A Pattern/Field Definition cannot have the same purpose as its meaning.

listitem.para: In cases where a Pattern has more than one field definition, we want the purpose and meaning to be unique for each field definition. If there is only one field definition it is okay if the meaning and purpose are the same but in general, we want to be as specific here as possible since the reasoner looks at these purpose and meaning Concepts to determine equivalence in Patterns.

section.title: Defining The Data Element
section.para: To represent a new standard in the Tinkar Logical Model, it is essential to determine the Patterns of the data set. Some Patterns will originate from the current Tinkar starter set, while others may be created specifically for the data set’s unique properties or reused from systems such as SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, or RxNorm.
In preparation for modeling in Tinkar, there are two approaches:

listitem.para: Starting from an existing system’s data set like SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, or RxNorm
Developing a new model using elements that might already exist and/or introducing brand new elements that need representation (e.g., LIDR).

section.para: The differences between predefined and new data sets are minimal. The main difference is that with a predefined data set, information about the model is usually well-documented, making it easier to identify a unique list of data elements and definitions. With a new data set, validating unique data elements and definitions may take more time.

To determine a data set’s Patterns, it is recommended to start by identifying all unique fields in the data set and assigning them a meaning, purpose, and definition. The term meaning refers to the Concept or idea that a word, phrase, symbol, or other form of communication represents. Within the Tinkar Reference Model, a meaning is applied to a field within a Semantic, indicating the type of information or data the field is designed to hold. For example, a field used to describe an SDO’s website would have the meaning 'URL,' implying that the field is meant to contain a URL. This is the specific type of data representing a web address.

The term ‘purpose’ refers to the specific role or function that a field within a Semantic is intended to serve. It provides broader context for why the field and its data exist within the model. For example, in the field describing an SDO’s website, the purpose is 'Website,' indicating that the field's role is to provide the website address, adding context to the meaning 'URL.'

For a data set that is part of a well-established source such as RxNorm and SNOMED CT®, field definitions can typically be found in online documentation of the terminology. For a data set that is not well-established, definitions may need to be created.

To illustrate a practical example of a predefined data set, the image below shows a snippet of the LOINC® transformation. LOINC® is a predefined data set with definitions and fields listed in its source file. In this snippet, some unique LOINC® fields provided in the data set are added to an Excel sheet in preparation. The purpose, meaning, and definitions are included to exemplify what these definitions should be.
Once unique data elements are recorded, they can be assessed to determine how they can be represented using current Tinkar Semantics, Concepts, and Patterns.

section.title: Determine Description Semantics
section.para: Since the goal is to reuse Tinkar Components as often as possible, the current Tinkar Patterns are reviewed first to determine where the new data set can be represented using those Patterns. It is advised to start with the Description Semantics. Description Semantics define how names and definitions are assigned to Components. Table 1 should be reviewed to determine what Concepts to use in the analyzed data set or if something new needs to be created. To understand how this has been done before, examples of terminology snippets from SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, and LIDR are provided below. As the following sections walk through modeling the Description Semantic, these snippets will be referred to as examples of how to model certain fields.
The example in the screenshot below, shows a row of SNOMED CT® data that will be used to demonstrate how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics.
Source: https://confluence.ihtsdotools.org/display/DOCRELFMT/4.2.2.+Description+File+Specification.
The example in the screenshot below shows a row of LOINC® data that will be used to demonstrate how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics.
Source: https://LOINC®.org/search/?t=1&s=7364-3.
The example in the screenshot below shows a row of RxNorm data that will be used to demonstrate how the data set was represented using the Description Semantics.

section.title: Field 1: Language
section.para: The first field value for the Description Semantic is assigned as a Language Concept. The purpose of the language field is to identify the Concept's language and description. The table below outlines the currently available languages to select from. If a specific language Concept does not exist in Tinkar, a new Concept to represent that language will need to be created.

row.entry: A Concept representing the English Language
A Concept representing the Spanish Language
A Concept representing the Chinese Language
A Concept representing the Czech Language
A Concept representing the Danish Language
A Concept representing the Dutch Language
A Concept representing the French Language
A Concept representing the German Language
A Concept representing the Irish Language
A Concept representing the Italian Language
A Concept representing the Korean Language
A Concept representing the Lithuanian Language
A Concept representing the Polish Language
A Concept representing the Russian Language
A Concept representing the Swedish Language

section.para: Upon revisiting the examples provided in section 3.2, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, the language Concept can represent language Code. In this case, 'en' would be used for English.

From the LOINC® export file, the English version has been obtained, so all descriptions can be represented by the language Concept and English can be. There was no explicit language field like there was in SNOMED CT, but since LOINC is primarily an American terminology we can assume we will use the English language to represent the Concept.
From the RxNorm export file, the English version has been obtained, so all descriptions can be represented by the language Concept and English can be used.

section.para: No new Concepts need to be created since the Languages above can be represented with existing Concepts in Tinkar.

listitem.para: Give the Concept a Fully Qualified Name of the specific language it is representing.
In the Stated Definition, add an is-A relationship to language under the necessary set.

section.title: Field 2: Description String
section.para: The Description String field is the literal string representation of the data, typically just the name of the element.

row.entry: The string value that represents the data.

section.para: Upon revisiting the examples provided in section 3.2, the following representations were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, the string value of the Term field ‘Chronic lung disease’ represents the Tinkar Description String value in the Description Semantic.
From the LOINC® export file, the string value of the Long Common Name ‘Meadow Fescue IgG Ab [Units/volume] in Serum’ represents the Tinkar Description String value in the Description Semantic.

From the RxNorm export file, the string value of the text inside the quotations ‘amlodipine 5 MG / hydrochlorothiazide 25 MG / olmesartan medoxomil 40 MG Oral Tablet’ represents the Tinkar Description String value in the Description Semantic.

section.para: No new Concepts need to be created since the above Description Strings can be represented with existing Concepts in Tinkar.

section.title: Field 3: Description Case Significance
section.para: Description case significance specifies how the capitalization of the string value should be handled, such as whether it is case sensitive or case insensitive. If the data has specific capitalization rules beyond existing Concepts, a new Concept will need to be created to represent it.

row.entry: Assumes the description is dependent on capitalization
Value which designates character as not sensitive for a given description

section.para: Upon revisiting the examples provided in section 3.2, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export, the caseSignificanceID can be represented using the Case Significance child Concept. Therefore, Description Not Case Sensitive would be used to represent its case significance.

In the LOINC® export file, there is no requirement to enforce case sensitivity on the long common name during a search. Therefore, Description Not Case Sensitive would be used to represent its case significance.

In the RxNorm export file, the RxNorm Name specifically incorporates certain capital letters with a particular purpose. Therefore, Description Not Case Sensitive would be used to represent its case significance.

section.para: No new Concepts need to be created since the above Description Case Significance can be represented with existing Concepts in Tinkar.

section.title: Field 4: Description Type
section.para: The description type field is used to determine the type of description the string represents for a Component. For example, the Fully Qualified Name is the primary way a Component is referred to. The Regular Name is any other common name or synonym referring to that Concept. The Definition description type can be used to provide a definition for any Concept. If none of the description types below represent the description specific to the data set, a new Concept would need to be created under Description Type to represent the new type of data.

row.entry: Specifying what type of description, it is i.e., is it fully qualified or regular and etc.
Semantic value indicating that the description type for the Description Pattern is a definition

Semantic value indicating that the description type for the Description Pattern is a fully qualified name. The fully qualified name is a unique description that differentiates a Concept from other similar Concepts.

Semantic value indicating that the description type for Description Patter is a regular name. This includes names that are not the fully qualified name, such as synonyms or other descriptions of a Concept.

section.para: Revisiting the examples provided in section 2.3, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, typeId is represented using one of the Description Types. Specifically, Synonym is represented using the Tinkar Regular Name Description Type.
From the LOINC® export file, the long common name can be represented using the Fully Qualified Name Description Type.
From the RxNorm export file, the RxNorm Name can be represented using the Fully Qualified Name Description Type.

section.para: No new Concepts need to be created since the above Description Types can be represented with existing Concepts in Tinkar.

section.title: Determine Identifier Semantics
section.para: Identifier Semantics are used to assign unique identifiers to Components that link to external data sources where the identifier is utilized. Although each Component in Tinkar is assigned a UUID, the original source and identifier of the data must be captured to reference back to the original source. For example, SNOMED CT® Identifiers and LOINC® IDs are stored and assigned to the Concepts they describe. Specific examples are detailed further in this section. The Identifier Pattern and its child Concepts are shown below.

row.entry: An identifier used to label the identity of a unique Component.
An identifier used to label the identity of a unique Component.
The literal string value associated as the ID
The literal string value associated as the ID

section.para: To understand how this has been done before, examples of terminology snippets from SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, and LIDR are provided below. As the following sections walk through modeling the Identifier Semantic, these snippets will be referred to as examples for how to model certain fields.
The example in the screenshot below shows a row of SNOMED CT® data used to illustrate how the data set was represented using the Identifier Semantics.
Source: https://confluence.ihtsdotools.org/display/DOCRELFMT/4.2.1+Concept+File+Specification
The example in the screenshot below shows a row of LOINC® data used to illustrate how the data set was represented using the Identifier Semantics.
Source: https://LOINC®.org/search/?t=1&s=7364-3.
The example in the screenshot below shows a row of RxNorm data used to illustrate how the data set was represented using the Identifier Semantics.

section.title: Field 1: Identifier Source
section.para: The Identifier Source is a unique identifier representing the data source from which it originates, such as SNOMED CT® or LOINC®. In cases where a data set is represented for the first time in Tinkar, the source may not yet exist, necessitating the creation of a new Concept.

row.entry: An identifier that uniquely represents a Concept in Tinkar

section.para: Upon revisiting the examples outlined in section 3.3, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, since the ID is not a UUID, a new Concept is required. This Concept, referred to as ‘SNOMED CT® Identifier Source’, becomes a child Concept of Identifier Source, and the Semantic Field Value references this newly created Concept.

From the LOINC® export file, the absence of an Identifier Source like in Example 1 necessitates the creation of a new ‘LOINC® Number’ Concept under Identifier Source, which is used for the Semantic Field Value.

entry.para: From the RxNorm export file, the assignment of two different Identifiers to the Concept results in two separate Identifier Semantics: one references the RxNorm CUI, while the other references the SNOMED CT® ID.

listitem.para: RxNorm CUI: a new Concept under Identifier Source, named ‘RxNorm CUI’, is required. This is the Semantic Field Value for the first Identifier Semantic.
SNOMED CT® ID: a new Concept needs to be created, or the Concept from Example 1 can be utilized if it was previously created in the model.

section.para: In these examples, each case needed a new Concept to represent the Unique Identifier.

section.title: Field 2: Identifier Value
section.para: The identifier value is the string representation of the Identifier, typically a random integer. Upon revisiting the examples provided in section 3.3, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: From the SNOMED CT® export file, the literal string value ‘413839001’ from the ID column is used for the field value.
From the LOINC® export file, the literal string value '7364-3' from the LOINC®_NUM column is used for the field value.

entry.para: From the RxNorm export file, as described in the previous example, two fields were created using two Semantics. The string value representing each ID is used for the field value:

section.title: Determine Stated Definition Semantics
section.para: The Stated Definition Semantic captures the unique relationships that define a Concept. This can be challenging to model because it requires determining which data elements fit into the existing stated definition versus those that need new Patterns and Semantics. In this step, it is essential to identify the properties of Concepts that make them unique, i.e., the underlying properties that differentiate one Concept from another in the model. The Stated Definition Pattern is depicted below, along with the meaning and purpose Concepts.

table.title: Stated Definition Meaning and Purpose Concepts

row.entry: Relationships/Axioms of a Concept that have been explicitly stated and defined
The Semantic value describing the purpose of the stated and inferred terminological axioms.
The relationships that uniquely define a Concept in EL++ description logic.
The Semantic value describing the purpose of the stated and inferred terminological axioms.

section.para: In cases where the data set is predefined, such as SNOMED CT® or RxNORM, the OWL Description Logic String is provided and transformed into the EL++ Stated Terminological Axioms. When creating a new model, the properties of EL++ Terminological Axioms must be examined to determine how to describe the uniqueness of the Concepts being modeled. The stated definition child Concepts are outlined below.

row.entry: A set of relationships that indicate something has an implication. Not necessary or sufficient, but implicated.
A set of relationships that is always true of a Concept.
A set of relationships that are non-defining and are not used by a description logic classifier.
A set of relationships that differentiate a Concept and its subtypes from all other Concepts. A Concept that contains at least one set of necessary and sufficient conditions is considered defined.
An association between a set of attribute or axiom value pairs that causes them to be considered together within a Concept definition or post-coordinated expression.

An abstract representation of a high-level role for a therapeutic medicinal product; these Concepts are not intended to describe detailed indications for therapeutic use or imply appropriateness in all clinical situations.
A Concept representing a particular kind of relationship between two entities, defining the specific function or responsibility one entity plays in relation to another.
The Concept referred to by the is_a axiom relationship or the axiom role relationship.

section.para: To understand how the Stated Definitions Semantic has been modeled, examples of terminology snippets from SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, RxNorm, and LIDR are provided below. As the following sections walk through modeling the Stated Definitions Semantic, these snippets will be referred to as examples for how to model certain fields.
The example in the screenshots below shows a SNOMED CT® Axiom example and its Axiom expression, illustrating how the data set was represented using the Stated Definitions Semantics.
Source: https://browser.LOINC®snomed.org/?perspective=full&ConceptId1=413839001&edition=MAIN/LOINC®/2023-10-15&release=&languages=en
LOINC® does not have an OWL String representation. However, the information below shows the data from LOINC® used to represent LOINC® using the Tinkar Stated Definitions Semantics.
Source: https://LOINC®.org/search/?t=1&s=7364-3
The example in the screenshot below shows the RxNorm OWL file, illustrating how the data was represented using the Stated Definitions Semantics.
Source File: https://lhncbc.nlm.nih.gov/RxNav/news/RxNorm-in-OWL.html

section.title: Determine Description Logic
section.para: Description logic aims to represent and characterize classes of objects and their relationships. SNOMED CT®, for example, uses description logic that corresponds to the EL++ language to define Stated and Inferred relationships and axioms. Given that all source files differ, not all contain OWL Description Logic. If they do contain an OWL Description Logic String, it should be utilized to avoid manually creating another string.
Upon revisiting the examples provided in section 3.4, the following representations and/or gaps were identified:

row.entry: Utilizing the owlExpression column allows for the representation of the field using the Tinkar description logic. This string can be imported using EL++ Description Logic, leading to the generation of Stated Axioms.

entry.para: LOINC® lacks an OWL String representation unless SNOMED CT®-LOINC® collaboration files are used, but these files are incomplete. Documentation reveals six main parts comprising a LOINC® Code:

Part definitions from LOINC® are treated as ‘Roles’ in the stated definition. ‘Role Type’ corresponds to one of the six parts above, and ‘Role Value’ corresponds to the Concept representation of the value.

listitem.para: To represent the data in the Stated Definitions Semantics, create a new Concept for each main LOINC® Part and a new Concept for each unique value for each of the six parts so they can be assigned in the LOINC® Code Role.

In addition to these six parts, there needs to be an ‘Is A’ relationship to designate the parent Concept. In the SNOMED CT®-LOINC® Collaboration, all LOINC® Concepts are listed as a child of ‘Observable Entity.’ Therefore, all LOINC® Codes will have an ‘Is A -> Observable Entity’ relationship.

entry.para: In the RxNorm OWL release file, the OWL Syntax literal string row can be used to represent the Tinkar description logic field in the Stated Definitions Semantics.

section.title: Create New Patterns
section.para: Once the current Patterns are analyzed and representation using Tinkar is determined, some outlying data may still need to be extended into new Patterns using the Tinkar Reference Model. This section reviews the steps for creating new Patterns.

section.title: Filter for Data Elements associated to Concepts
section.para: Start by filtering data elements associated with the Concept being modeled. Focus on these elements rather than those describing other data elements in the file. Since Semantics refer to any Component (any Concept, Pattern, or Semantic), begin with the Patterns that refer to the Concepts being modeled.

In SNOMED CT®, there are descriptions and dialects. Descriptions are modeled first since they reference actual Concepts (Semantic referring to a Concept), while Dialects refer to those Descriptions (Semantic referring to a Semantic).

In LOINC®, there is a data element for STATUS. This directly describes an attribute of a LOINC® Concept. However, there are additional data elements such as STATUS_REASON, STATUS_TEXT, and CHANGE_REASON_PUBLIC. These additional data elements do not directly describe attributes of the LOINC® Concept itself but are descriptive attributes of the STATUS.

section.title: Group by similar data elements
section.para: Group data fields with similar elements together. Elements with similar purposes and occurrences should be grouped together in a Pattern. These elements do not always need to have the same values across Concepts. Once the related Concepts are represented, these groupings will become new Patterns.

In RxNorm, HUMAN_DRUG and PRESCRIBABLE are two data elements that are closely related and often seen together, but it is not expected for them to occur with a field like VET_DRUG. In this case, to add these three data elements, two different Patterns are needed:

section.title: Determine Field Types
section.para: After grouping the new properties into the new Patterns that need to be modeled, each data element will be treated as a field type. For each field, determine how to represent it in the model. Below is a list of field types, with the official list available in Tinkar core.

row.entry: A display field type that references a Concept ID.
A display field that references an ordered list of Concept IDs.
A display field that references an unordered list of Concept IDs.
A display field that references a di-graph whose edges are ordered pairs of vertices. Each edge can be followed from one vertex to another vertex.
A display field that references a graph obtained from an undirected tree by replacing each undirected edge by two directed edges with opposite directions.
A data type that represents values as high-precision fractional values.
A data type that represents some range of mathematical integers
A sequence of characters, either as a literal constant or as a variable. Strings could be used to represent terms from code systems or URLs, textual definitions, etc.
A data type that represents one of two possible values, typically true or false.
A data type that represents a visual representation, such as a photo or graphic.
A data type that represents a specific point in time, often with high precision.
A data type that represents very large or very precise decimal numbers.
A data type that represents a sequence of bytes, often used for binary data.
A universally unique identifier, a 128-bit number used to uniquely identify information in computer systems.

section.para: The most common field types are the Component Field, Component Set Field, and String Field. Things to consider:

listitem.para: If it is a unique element that can vary significantly between Concepts and rarely has a chance of two Concepts having the same value, it should be treated as a String or something similar.

If the value for the data element might be common across different Concepts being modeled, consider making that value its own Concept and treat this field as a Component Field with the value of that Concept.

If there could be multiple values for the data element that can be shared or common across different Concepts, a Component Set Field can be used, and all the values can be modeled as different Concepts within the ‘set’.

section.para: To represent the LOINC® ClassType, a new Pattern must be created. The LOINC® ClassType can be defined using a semantic of this new pattern on a LOINC® Code. When creating a new pattern for a Semantic, there are two different choices to make. The first decision is how many field definitions the Pattern should have. The second decision is what data type should use for the field definitions. Patterns specify what type of data are in the Semantic fields. However, the number of fields can vary depending on what type of data you are trying to represent.

Patterns do not have to have field definitions. These types of patterns are called Membership Patterns. The purpose and meaning of the Pattern specify the Semantic value themselves, so a field is not needed. Using LOINC ClassType, four new patterns can be created. The purpose of the Patterns would be similar and have the same ClassType concept value, but their meaning would be different and dependent on the actual value. The result would be each LOINC Code having a semantic of one of the four corresponding patterns.

table.title: LOINC® ClassType Patterns with No Field Definitions

section.para: Using No Field Definitions only works with properties that have a small set of possible values. If there are a significant number of possible values, it is better to use a field definition as shown below.

To display the ClassType in a field definition for a Pattern, determine if any other Data Elements should be captured. For example, both the LOINC Class and ClassType can be captured in a single pattern using separate Field Definitions for each as shown below.

table.title: LOINC® Class Pattern with Field Definitions

section.para: In this example, the Class and ClassType are captured in a single pattern since they are closely related. The Field Type is assigned as a Concept Field. A good indication to use a Concept Field is if the Value itself has properties that should be modeled.

section.title: Build Data Model and Starter Data

listitem.para: The Data Model is created using a modeling tool, mapping out the Patterns, Semantics, and Concepts
Examples of current data models will be added here with descriptions.

figure.title: Build Data Model and Starter Data

section.title: Validating Models
section.para: To create a stable and reliable model, each must undergo a validation process. The validation process involves two key roles:

listitem.para: Domain Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) provide critical feedback based on their specialized knowledge.
Tinkar Reference Modelers, who initially build and document the model, and additional modelers provide insights on reusing current Tinkar Components, ensuring correct reuse.

section.para: The goal of this validation process is to achieve consensus on a stable model agreed upon by all relevant parties, providing a solid foundation that ensures the model's accuracy and reliability for future developments. The validation process involves three key steps: conducting peer review sessions, reviewing the model with domain SMEs, and having review cycles, and reaching a group consensus on the model's final state.

When the initial model is complete, modelers should collect and create documentation of the model. This documentation should include the logical data model drawing and all modeling decisions, including reused Tinkar Patterns, Concepts, and Semantics, as well as new Concepts, Patterns, and/or Semantics created. The rationale behind the decisions made should also be included. Modelers should also work with other modelers to conduct peer review sessions to discuss the modeling decisions and rationale, and to reach agreed-upon decisions about the model.

Once the initial model is complete, documentation is gathered, and the model has been peer-reviewed, the modelers should review it with the domain SME(s). The domain SME(s) should ensure the information requirements are met and the information is modeled in an agreed-upon way. All rationale for decisions, any questions the modelers may have, and any viable options for modeling certain aspects should be given to the domain SME(s) for review.

Feedback gathered from the domain SME(s) should be captured and incorporated into the model. The modelers should then review the model again with the SMEs. The feedback process may continue for some time, but eventually, when all feedback has been discussed and implemented where applicable, the model should be finalized, and all documentation of the changes and history of the model should be shared.

section.title: Model Documentation
section.para: Throughout the modeling process, modelers should capture documentation describing the rationale for decisions made, create the starter data set, and develop the logical data model. The table below describes the different types of artifacts modelers should provide once the modeling is complete. It is recommended to upload documentation to be stored on Confluence.

row.entry: Documentation captured during the modeling process that explains the reasoning behind modeling decisions, any assumptions made, and the decisions for fields in the data set represented using Tinkar.
A list of any new Tinkar Components that should be created to represent the data set.
A logical model representation of any new Patterns, Semantics, and Concepts.
A fundamental part of the Tinkar model, which can be a Concept, Pattern, or Semantic, each represented by UUIDs.
A Component in Tinkar identified by UUIDs and a STAMP, containing only information within the STAMP.
Codes for vaccines administered, which may overlap with RxNorm codes.

entry.link: IIS | Code Sets | CVX | Vaccines | CDC

row.entry: Logical Observation Identifiers, Names, and Codes
The interpretation or explanation field for a Pattern/Semantics, indicating the type of information a field is designed to hold.
A Component that describes the fields and field types for a table, similar to a database schema, used to specify the structure needed to provide meaning to a Component.
The specific role or function that a field within a Semantic is intended to serve, providing context for why the field and its data exist within the model.
A standardized nomenclature for clinical drugs, providing codes for medications.

entry.para: Relating to or involving data which is structured and tagged according to its meaning or intention, allowing it to be read directly by computers.

row.entry: Semantic, adj. meanings, etymology and more | Oxford English Dictionary (oed.com)
Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms

A logical model designed to establish a robust knowledge architecture, integrating local systems with medical and laboratory terminologies to facilitate effective communication of clinical information across multiple systems.

section.title: Tinkar Starter Data (Listed in alphabetical order)

row.entry: Specifies that a description is acceptable, but not preferred within a language or dialect.
Concept used to represent a status for Components that are active.
Concept used to represent a status for Components that are canceled
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
A display field type that references a Concept ID.
A display field that references an ordered list of Concept IDs.
A display field that references an unordered list of Concept IDs.
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Value which designates character as not sensitive for a given description
Semantic value describing the description type for the description Pattern is a definition
Human readable text for a Concept
Whether a given human readable text for a Concept is permissible
Assumes the description is dependent on capitalization
Specifies how to handle the description text in terms of case sensitivity
Contains all metadata and human readable text that describes the Concept
Purpose and meaning for the description Pattern and dialect Patterns
Specifying what type of description, it is i.e., is it fully qualified or regular and etc.
The Semantic meaning for the EL++ Patterns
A path that specifies that the Components are currently under development

entry.link: Specifies the dialect of the language.

row.entry: A display field that references a di-graph whose edges are ordered pairs of vertices. Each edge can be followed from one vertex to another vertex.
A display field that references a graph obtained from an undirected tree by replacing each undirected edge by two directed edges with opposite directions.
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Specifies the dialect of the English language
Existential restrictions describe objects that participate in at least one relationship along a specified property to objects of a specified class.
Represents values as high-precision fractional values.
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Fully qualified name is a description that uniquely identifies and differentiates it from other Concepts with similar descriptions
Particular form of language specific form of English language, particular to Great Britian
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Great Britain: English Language reference set
An identifier Pattern is used to identity a Concept which contains the identifier source and the actual value
An identifier used to label the identity of a unique Component.
A set of relationships that indicate something has an implication. Not necessarily or sufficient but implicated.
Concept used to represent a status for Components that are no longer active
The origins and destinations for Concepts based on the reasoner generated inferred terminological axioms
A Pattern specifying the origins and destinations for Concepts based on the inferred terminological axioms
A data type that represents some range of mathematical integers

entry.emphasis: MODEL_CONCEPT; PATTERN; STATUS_VALUE; USER; MODULE; PATH

row.entry: Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Specifies the language of the description text.
The Semantic value indicating which language is used in the description text
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
The Semantic value describing the purpose of the stated and inferred terminological axioms.
The interpretation or explanation field for a Pattern/Semantics
A set of relationships that is always true of a Concept.
A set of assets under version control that can be managed distinctly from other assets. Paths ‘branch’ from other paths when established and can be ‘merged’ with other paths as well.
A Pattern is a set of display fields and values that can be asserted about a Concept
A unique thought, fact, or circumstance
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
Specifies that a description is preferred within a language or dialect. There will be one preferred description for each description type.
Concept used to represent a status for Components that have not yet been released and exist in their most basic form.
The reason for which a Tinkar value in a Pattern was created or for which it exists.
There may be descriptions/synonyms marked as ‘regular.’
Signifies path to child Concepts which are more specific than the Tinkar term
Signifies path to parent Concepts which are more general than the Tinkar term

Is an abstract representation of a high-level role for a therapeutic medicinal product; the Concepts are not intended to describe a detailed indication for therapeutic use nor imply that therapeutic use is appropriate in all clinical situations.
An association between a set of attribute or axiom value pairs that causes them to be considered together within a Concept definition or post coordinated expression.
Concept that is used to describe universal vs existential restrictions.

Refers to a Concept that represents a particular kind of relationship that can exist between two entities. It defines the specific function or responsibility that one entity plays in relation to another.
Value for the description language dialect
Value for the description language dialect
A path for Components under testing.
Value for the description language dialect

A Pattern specifying the origins and destinations for Concepts based on the stated terminological axioms
The status of the STAMP Coordinate(Active, Cancelled, Inactive, Primordial)
a sequence of characters, either as a literal constant or as a variable. Strings could be used to represent terms from code systems or URLs, textual definitions, etc.
A set of relationships that differentiate a Concept and its subtypes from all other Concepts. A Concept that contains at least one set of necessary and sufficient conditions is considered defined.
Value for the description language dialect

Universal restrictions constrain the relationships along a given property to Concepts that are members of a specific class.
A universally unique identifier that uniquely represents a Concept in Tinkar

section.title: Archive
section.para: From the OWL Expressions, a set of stated relationships or axioms are automatically created through a reasoner. An alternative to having the description logic string can be to simply create the stated definition axioms inside of a Tinkar application like Komet directly. Here are the Stated Definition Axioms for each example:

listitem.para: Add an Is-A relationship to ‘Observable Entity’
Role Value would be ‘Festuca elatior Ab.IgG’
